creator: nick@svana.org
text:
When a path like structure is defined, but does not yet exist, a BuildExcpetion
will be logged before it is even referenced. Would a warning be better? In 
fact, in my situation it would be better that the warning occurs only when the 
path is first referenced and still does exist.

My build file has a dist target that depends on a build target. The build 
target creates the directory 
(D:\work\mindmatics\packages\sessionpkg\build\tar\lib) that causes the 
exception when the dist target is called.

dist:
Caught exception (org.apache.tools.ant.BuildException) while expanding 
project.run.classpath: D:\work\mindmatics\packages\sessionpkg\build\tar\lib not 
found.

Using: Apache Ant version 1.6alpha compiled on June 6 2003

Hmm, the logged exception is supposed to be the warning message - maybe the text
is not intuitive?

If the path still cannot be resolved when you use it, you'll not only receive a
warning but the build will fail.
creator: bodewig@apache.org
nick@svana.org
text:
I don't find "Caught exception (org.apache.tools.ant.BuildException)"
 intuitive. 

To me it looks more like an error coming from ant and not a warning about
something in my build script.

Maybe just:
warn: project.run.classpath: 
D:\work\mindmatics\packages\sessionpkg\build\tar\lib not found.


Should I submit a patch for this?
Would be better.

Sorry, I didn't see that you explicitly asked whether you should submit a patch.

Of course!  Patches are always welcome.

I'm just afraid that you'll find that it is harder than you think.  The code
generating the warning is the exception handler in Project#addReference - around
line 1755 in CVS HEAD.
creator: bodewig@apache.org

text: the code that emitted this warning has been removed in Ant 1.6.
